report_title: Industry Report on Fire Protection and Security System Installation Contractors
executive_summary: Fire protection and security system installation contractors have struggled through the current period as companies cope with economic uncertainty, high interest rates and poor business and consumer sentiment. Companies have faced severe volatility, especially during the pandemic. Business closures and reduced corporate profit led to subdued demand for fire protection and security systems from nonresidential markets. Even so, roaring housing starts and elevated private spending on home improvement supported residential markets and prevented greater exposure to the pandemic downturn.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The pandemic cuts demand for fire protection and security system installation contractors
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic posed a prolonged challenge for most contractors. Nonresidential construction markets plummeted amid lockdown restrictions and business closures. Most companies pushed off new construction projects, limiting demand for security and fire protection systems. This trend forced many companies, especially nonemployers, to exit the industry altogether.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Construction Markets Struggle as Interest Rates Rise
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Interest rates have skyrocketed following the pandemic, preventing the construction sector's complete recovery. Mortgage and borrowing rates have trampled homeowner sentiment, slashing housing starts and leading to notable revenue drops. Similarly, many businesses have remained hesitant to start new construction projects due to high borrowing costs. Even so, office vacancy rates have declined as employees return to work. In particular, pent-up demand for travel has led to booming demand for new security systems from the accommodation sector.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Contractors Will Benefit From Stabilizing Economic Conditions
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Residential and nonresidential construction activity will recover as interest rates ease through the outlook period. In particular, new construction activity will rebound, creating notable opportunities for contractors since most states legally require smoke detectors in new projects. Similarly, corporate profit will soar through the outlook period, encouraging greater business activity and expansion. Many companies will open up new offices and facilities, necessitating smoke detectors and security systems. This trend will be especially important given the nonresidential market's revenue share.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Clients Will Demand More Advanced Products
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Upstream manufacturers have created increasingly advanced products to appeal to tech-savvy consumers. Many products prioritize connectivity and remote control and are significantly more expensive than other options, leading to greater returns. These products will continue to grow in popularity through the outlook period, encouraging more contractors to offer advanced security and fire safety solutions. In many cases, contractors offering newer products will gain a clear competitive advantage.

industry_definition: Fire protection and security system installation contractors are primarily engaged in installing and servicing electrical wiring and equipment of fire suppression and security systems for residences and businesses. Companies may perform new work, install new systems or maintain equipment.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - increasing

key_trends: Construction markets have struggled through the current period.
The pandemic and high interest rates posed major challenges to contractors, especially for new projects.
New technology can create opportunities for companies. Consumers have increasingly preferred integrated solutions to monitor multiple fire and security systems remotely.
Most states legally require smoke detectors in new construction. This legislation indirectly provides government support but businesses receive no direct federal, state or local government support.
Companies must abide by safety regulations during installation.
Most states require licenses to install, repair and monitor smoke detectors and fire alarms.
Most states require up-to-date smoke and heat detectors. These laws create stable demand for fire protection installation compared with other segments.
Nonresidential markets primarily drive demand. Climbing interest rates and weak corporate profit have threatened new construction, severely limiting growth opportunities.
Competition often varies by region. Populated areas have significantly higher saturation leading to greater price competition
Contractors can succeed by offering value-added services
Many companies have prioritized super after-installation services, like warranties and repairs, while others offer a wider range of interconnected devices.

Companies have purchased increasingly advanced systems to match consumer demand. Even so, contractors often pass climbing costs onto clients or develop strong supplier relationships to mitigate cost volatility.
Companies rely on skilled labor to install and monitor security and fire systems. Many states require contractors to obtain licenses to work in this industry, boosting wage expenses.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Businesses represent the overwhelming majority of demand for fire protection and security system installation contractors. Manufacturers often represent the strongest demand for fire safety systems. This segment faltered during the pandemic as many businesses held onto cash, putting off security upgrades. Similarly, business birth rates stalled, limiting demand from new businesses. Like household markets, businesses have struggled as interest rates climb. The nonresidential market also struggled during the pandemic as business activity declined. This market has recovered as governments lift lockdown restrictions and corporate profit expands, enabling more spending.

Households, including single-family and multi-family structures, are a stable source of demand for fire protection and security system installation contractors since most states require houses and large residential buildings to have functioning smoke alarms and other fire prevention systems. Most households install smoke and carbon monoxide alarms that connect to general security systems. Some apartments may have sprinklers in hallways. Multiunit housing projects often represent a greater portion of household demand. Weak residential markets and climbing interest rates have severely stifled housing starts, existing home sales and private investment in home improvements. These metrics have limited household investment in new security and fire protection systems.

Federal, state and local governments represent a stable source of demand for contractors. Government funding often has fewer fluctuations compared with residential and nonresidential construction spending.

Contractors also receive demand from nonprofit organizations but this market represents a slim percentage of total demand. Successful installation contractors manage clients across multiple markets to mitigate the impact of economic downturns.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Security System and Lock Installation without Monitoring
products_and_services.product_description: This segment represents security and alarm system services with monitoring alongside security system and lock installation without monitoring. Many companies offer advanced security monitoring and response to gain a competitive edge.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Fire Alarm Control Panels and Integrated Systems
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes smoke and heat detectors, fire alarm control panels and integrated systems. Single-family houses often have basic systems, while apartments or businesses commonly have more complex and expensive fire protection systems.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: SECURITY SYSTEM DEMAND VARIES BY MARKET
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment represents security and alarm system services with monitoring alongside security system and lock installation without monitoring. Many companies offer advanced security monitoring and response to gain a competitive edge.

Security offerings often vary significantly by residential and nonresidential market; building size differences also necessitate vastly different security solutions. Many companies have offered integrated systems, enabling clients to view cameras, lock doors and manage other options from a single device.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: MOST STATES LEGALLY REQUIRE SMOKE AND FIRE SYSTEMS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment includes smoke and heat detectors, fire alarm control panels and integrated systems. Single-family houses often have basic systems, while apartments or businesses commonly have more complex and expensive fire protection systems. Nearly all US states require new construction projects to hardwire smoke detectors; some states carry stricter requirements for smoke detectors, fire alarms and carbon monoxide alarms.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Fire protection and security system installation is highly labor-intensive, involving skilled manual labor for a wide range of installation, maintenance and after-sale services activities. Installation processes are often extremely technical. In most states, contractors that install or maintain security or fire alarm systems need licenses, leading to higher wage costs.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE PANDEMIC AND CLIMBING INTEREST RATES THREATEN GROWTH
volatility_points.volatility_description: Nonresidential construction activity plummeted during the pandemic as lockdowns restricted business activity and office vacancies climbed, threatening the industry's largest market and leading to notable revenue declines. Even so, residential construction growth, highlighted by mounting housing starts and home improvement spending, stabilized revenue at the height of the pandemic. Similarly, soaring interest rates have stifled construction activity following the pandemic, contributing to the industry's overall decline through the current period. Contractors have struggled with lackluster demand for new residential and nonresidential construction.
